result.execSummary:
The defendant Tanner Lee Raymond was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Armed Robbery with Threat of Force [Modifiers: Repeater, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.32(2).
  • Felon Possess Firearm [Modifiers: Repeater, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 941.29(2)(a).
  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: Use of a Dangerous Weapon, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Repeater, Use of a Dangerous Weapon], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

of Sentencing Hearing held on July 21, 2015
Counts 13 & 22 Jail JOC
Count 16 & 17 JOC

10:03 a.m. Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in court with attorney Karl Alexander Schmidt. Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin. PSI Report writer appears via phone. Parties have received and reviewed the PSI report.  DA Molepski asked the PSI writer for clarification of prison program eligibility. DA Molepski makes sentencing recommendation. Ct 16: 17 yr prison at 7 yrs In & 10 yrs ES, Ct 17: 3 yrs In & 3 yrs ES, cts 18 & 22: 6 mo jail each.
10:35 a.m. Atty Karl Schmidt concurs in part with the state's recommendation and states there is 234 days credit and request concurrent sentences.
10:45 a.m. Defendant makes apologetic statments to the Court.
BTC: *****************PRISON****
Count 16: Felony: Armed Robbery - Firearm:  Prison at 7 yrs  Incarceration and 8 yrs  Extended Supervision; 234 days credit. Concurrent with any other sentence
Conditions of Supervision:
Pay restitution $1,938 joint/several. Pay with 25% prison account.
Maintain full-time employment.
Maintain absolute sobriety.
Do not possess any firearms or other dangerous weapons.
No contact with the victims or co-defendants, unless approved in advance and in writing by the Agent
Letters of apology to victims, give to agent first.
Complete all other programming as deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment and the Department of Correction.
Set up payment plan to pay resitution and/or if the other co-defendant(s) pays it, then need to repay that co-defendant(s) at least 1/3 of it.
Pay costs and DNA surcharge.
Not eligible for challenge or substance abuse programs.

Count 17: Felony: Felon Possess Firearm: 3 yrs In & 3 yr ES, concurrent with ct 16 and another sentence currently serving: Comply with same conditions of supervision as stated in Ct 16. Pay costs and DNA surcharge.

Count 18: Misd: Criminal Damage:  6 mo Jail, concurrent with each other and any other sentence. Pay costs and DNA surcharge.
Count 22: Misd: Resist/Obstruct: 6 mo Jail, concurrent with each other and any other sentence. Pay costs and DNA surcharge.
Sentencing hearing at 07-21-2015 09:30 am

Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in court with attorney Karl Alexander Schmidt. Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
1:34 p.m.  Court calls case.  Atty Molepske states appearances.  A plea agreement has been reached.  Atty Molepske states the agreement for Counts 16, 17, 18 and 22.  Atty Molepske states an additional agreement that the Defendant cooperate with other pending cases.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Atty Schmidt will withdraw his Motion for Suppression filed February 23, 2015, and any other currently pending Motions.

Atty Schmidt states the Defendant has signed the agreement, along with Atty Molepske.
Atty Molepske states Counts 19, 20, 21 and 23 will be dismissed and readin.
Court questions the Defendant regarding his signature on the documents.
  
Defendant enters a plea of: 
Count 16:   Guilty
Count 17:   Guilty
Count 18:   Guilty
Count 22:   Guilty

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty on all four Counts.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.

Counsel is requesting a PSI.

BY THE COURT:  Court will order a Presentence Investigation to be done by the Department of Corrections.  The Report is to be made available one week before sentencing.  Sentencing is scheduled for July 21, 2015 at 9:30 a.m.  Courts, 19, 20, 21 and 23 are dismissed and readin.  Court does revoke bond.

2:17 p.m.  Case is back on the record.  Atty Molepske states that the bond has been revoked, but would like a condition of confinement to be no contact with the Defendant's co-defendants, Destiny Clinton and Harland Raymond.
  Sentencing hearing scheduled for July 21, 2015 at 09:30 am.
Notice of and State's Brief in Response to the Court's Request for Brieifing of an Oral Argument and Opposition to Defendant's Motion to Suppress Evidence
in Support of Defendant's Motion to Suppress Evidence and to Compel Discovery
Motion Hearing held 5/6/15
Final pre-trial at 06-08-2015 10:00 am

Exhibit #P1 Copy of Message from Defendant 
    Exhibit #P2 Copy of Miranda Warning 
    Exhibit #P3 DVD - Interview of Defendant by Det. Coey (not scanned)
    Exhibit #P4 DVD - Interview of Defendant by Det. Meidl (not scanned)
    Exhibit #P5 Copy of Miranda Form

Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in court with attorney Karl Alexander Schmidt. Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Continuation of the Motion hearing: 

BY THE COURT:  Regarding the January 8th interview, the Defendant was represented by counsel at the adjourned initial appearance on 12/22 and a prelim was held on 12/29 in which the defendant appeared with attorney Schmidt and the defendant waived his right to preliminary hearing at that time.  The defendant was held and the defendant pleaded not guilty. On 1/6, an amended information was filed.  So the defendant clearly had counsel on 1/8 and he did not request the contact with the police officer.  When the officer retrieved him from the jail and read him his miranda warnings as listed on Ex 5, the defendant waived his right to Miranda and chose to speak without a lawyer present.  Court does wish to have additional briefing on the issue as to whether the defendant effectively waives 6th amendment to counsel at the prelim and arraignment and has not left custody.  Court will give the parties time to do that.  Court is also concerned that discovery was not provided to defense counsel as timely, which would seem appropriate and did hinder defendse counsel preparation for this hearing.  Court will allow counsel to also revisit the issue whether counsel was actually invoked as to whetjer the officer should not have had contact with the defendant without him asking to contact first.  

Parties to brief the issue in 2 weeks.  
Briefs to be filed by both parties regarding the January 8th interview by May 22nd. 
Response briefs to be filed by both parties by June 5th if they so choose. 
If the Court did suppress, then it would be what is the suppressed statements and that would be the statements made on January 8th and what is derived from that statement.
Defendant did voluntarily give a statement on the 8th, whether that's admissable or not or admissable even if the defendant takes the stand to the contrary.  If it was simply a miranda violation, that statement is usually able to be used for impeachment.  Not sure if that is for a 6th amendment violation. 

Atty Molepske questions the Court if he waived the 6th amendment and 5th amendment.
BY THE COURT: Court finds he waived 5th and 6th amendment rights on the January 7th statements.  Court is not convinced he waived his 6th amendment rights on the January 8th date.  

Final Pre-Trial on 6/8/15 at 10:00.

Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in court with attorney Karl Alexander Schmidt. Defendant Tanner Lee Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
2:58 p.m.  Court calls the case. 

Court has just handled some motions on a related file with Harlon Raymond.  

Motion to Introduce DNA Evidence and Evidence of Flight: 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court.  
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT: Court will not rule at this time, but will wait until evidence at trial. 

Notice of Intent to Use DNA Evidence:
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  State has provided the results as quickly as possible after they received it and providing it at today's hearing.  Court understands the defense has a right to review those results and make decisions as to how they want to respond.  Court will allow for reasonable time to respond.  With regards to dates things were done, Court encourages the State to review with the law enforcement to make sure State has everything law enforcement has and defense has everything the State has. 

Motion in Limine: 
#1 & #2 -
Atty Schmidt makes statements to the Court.  Withdraws the objection to #2. 
All witnesses sequestered with the exception of Josh Ostrowski. 
Court questions if the victim will be in the courtroom that is also a witness.  if that witness is a fact witness who could be impacted by other witnesses testimony that witness shoudl be called before them or not be in the courtroom
Atty Molepske indicates the witness will be called early in the trial. 
Atty Schmidt makes statemetns to the Court.  If early is first, he has no problem with her observing. Asks to be sequestered until she has completed her testimoney. 
BY THE COURT: Atty Molepske to dicuss that with the victim.  If there is going to be an issue, it will need to be addressed before trial. 

#3 - 
Statutory.  
Atty Schmidt asks for the Sate to file a witness list. 
BY THE COURT:  State will be providing sooner rather than later with a list of prior criminal convictions. 
Atty Molepske makes additional statements. 

#4 - 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court. Asks the defendant to answer 3. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court.  Believes the proper number is 5. 
Court questions Atty Schmidt. 
Atty Schmidt responds. 
BY THE COURT:  Court finds offenses are related.  All 5 should be counted because they are so recent.  Defendant has not evidenced any rehabiliation so that they should not be counted.  Motion is granted.  The defendant should respond with 5. 

#5 - 
Atty Schmidt indicates this is pretty standard. 
BY THE COURT:  Granted. 

#6 - 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court.  
Court questions Atty Schmidt. 
Atty Schmidt could probably come to an agreement about some statements. 
BY THE COURT:  Motion is held open. 

#7 - 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court cannot specifically rule on a question in advance.  All parties understand there is a heresay rule and only under circumstances can a defendant get his own statements in thru another witness.  Court will not take direct action but is aware that issue may come up at trial and will be prepared to rule at the time. 

#8 - 
BY THE COURT:  Court will not make a specific ruling.  Court does recognize the Rule of Evidence and what they require. 

#9, #10 & #12 -
Atty Schmidt makes statements. Agrees he has been placed on notice.  Believes #10 and #12 can be ruled on the same way. 
Court would need a motion.  
BY THE COURT:  Court agrees with Atty Schmidt.  Court will not make a specific ruling on 10 and 12.  If it comes up at trial, it will rule on then. 

#11 - 
BY THE COURT:  Court allows jurors to take notes but not during opening statement or closing arguments. 

Motion to Admit Other Acts Evidence: 
State provides a copy of this motion to the Court that is unsigned but conforms to the signed copy. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Molepske. 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Schmidt. 
Atty Schmidt makes additional arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  The theft of the AK47 style rifle the day before the robbery is relevant.  Puts the gun that was allegedly used in the defendant's hands.  That is a fact that is probative.  Court finds it is relevant and not unduly prejudicial and may be used as an appropriate purpose. 

With regards to the next Act related to Theft of Firearm for an incident on 11/29/2014:  
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Molepske. 

3:53 p.m. Court takes a 5 minute recess at this time. 

4:05 p.m.  Court is back in session. 
Atty Molepske makes additional arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court had not heard sufficient factors to allow for the Kalk burglary.  Court will not allow that Other Acts Evidence. 
Atty Schmidt makes statements. 

Atty Molepske questions the Court.  Evidence as it relates to prior to the Wigwam robbery as to relates to what the defendant stated.  State did not file an Other Acts motion where they went to 2 gas stations but did not complete them.  If there will be an objection by defense, he will seek to file another Other Acts Motion. 
Court questions Atty Molepske. 
BY THE COURT:  Court indicates it is part of the crime.  That is relevant and not other acts evidence.  If counsel disagrees, invites a Motion in Limine for that.  
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court.  Asks the court to note his objection. 

Defense Motions in Limine: 
#1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 13 & 12 have already been dealt with.

#10 - 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court.  Witnesses should not refer to the weapon as an automatic.  
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court denies the motion because the Court isn't going to dictate to witnesses what they testify to.  They are subject to cross examination.  

Order striking paragraph 6. 
Atty Schmidt makes statements to the Court. 

Defense Motion to Suppress In Custody Statements that were made to Meidl and Coey on 7th and 8th: 
Atty Schmidt makes arguments to the Court.  There is video of those statements.  State provided with the video statements.  The objection is that those were statements made involuntarily. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
4:23 p.m.  Det. J. Coey is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Molepske. 
Exhibit #1 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff. 
Exhibit #2 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff. 
Exhibit #3 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff, moved for admission, no objection subject to cross exam.  BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #3 is received. 
DVD is played beginning at 10:30:59 a.m. and ending at 10:32:28 a.m. 
Direct exam by Atty Molespke continues. 
DVD is played beginning at 10:32:28 a.m. and ending at 10:35:45 a.m.  
Direct exam by Atty Molepske continues. 
Cross exam by Atty Schmidt. 

4:47 p.m. Det. J. Meidl is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Molepske. 
Exhibit #4 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff, moved for admission, no objection subject to cross exam.  BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #4 is received. 
DVD is played beginning at 2:29:36 p.m. and ending at 2:31:59 p.m. 
Direct exam by Atty Molepske continues. 
Exhibit #5 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff. 
Atty Molepske makes statements.  Would be playing more of the video if requested. 
Atty Schmidt makes statements.  Looking to have everything suppressed.  
Court questions Atty Schmidt.  
Atty Schmidt makes additional statemetns.  Agrees there is no loud voice or overt coercion played on the audio recording that he had heard. 
Direct exam continues by Atty Molepske. 
Witness identifies the defendant. 

Atty Molepske moves for the admission of the exhibits. 
No objections by Atty Schmidt. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibits #1 thru #5 are received. 

Cross exam by Atty Schmidt. 

Atty Schmidt asks the court to take judicial notice of the dates. 
Court questions Atty Schmidt. 
Atty Schmidt responds. 
BY THE COURT:  Court notes there is a notice of retainer in the file that was filed with the Court on 12/12/2014.  

Atty Schmidt makes final arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Schmidt. 
Atty Schmidt questions his defendant. 
Defendant responds. 
Atty Schmidt makes additional statements. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions both counsel. 
Atty Schmidt makes additional arguments to the Court. 
Atty Molepske makes additional arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT: 
Court first addresses the January 7th interview by Detective Coey: 
Court finds that on 1/2/15, Defendant was in custody at the jail.  He was in custody for this offense.  Det. Coey was one of the investigators on this case.  Defendant sent a note marked as Exhibit #1.  On 1/7, Det. Coey was wearing street clothes, side arm and badge.  He and defendant were acquainted thru past professional contacts.  Defendant knew Det. Coey was a law enforcement officer.  The defendant started explaining the note and a conversation was conducted.  The Det. almost immediately pulled out the Miranda warning marked as Exhibit #2.  The Det. read verbatim the miranda warnings and initialed as he read them.  Det. ask if the defendant understood those rights and the defendant stated he did.  Then signed the waiver of rights form.  There is no indication that the defendant was under any pressure or threatened in any way to waive those rights.  Det. never used a loud voice or yelled or intimidated the defendant in any way.  Exhibit #3 was observed by the Court.  Defendant appeared to be comfortable and voices were normal and relaxed.  Court finds the defendant did initiate contact with the police and the police did fully advise the defendant of his rights and the defendant volutarily waived his right and gave a voluntary statement.  Court finds the defendant fully understood those rights.
of Karl A. Schmidt
